subject: Re: [junit] Digest Number 778
msgSnippet: ... From: J. B. Rainsberger  ... Well, like I said, I have seen the use of unit testing be a foot in the door - or part of one
messageBody:
----- Original Message -----
From: "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbr@...>



> Oh, I know. I've worked for them. I'm in the XPAdoption group, trying
> to figure out how to change all that. I'm convinced that the only thing
> to do is to start my own shop, but I don't have the business and
> marketing knowledge to run it, nor do I have the funds to pay someone
> else to run it on day one.

Well, like I said, I have seen the use of unit testing be a "foot in the
door" - or part of one anyway; I worked for a company that went from doing
almost no testing, to adopting many XP practices and having developers write
unittests for their own code before checking it in. Some even did TDD. Part
of the foot in the door was that the project was a whole new practice that
the project manager convinced management to let him use some XP practices,
mixed in with things like JAD and so on. It worked out fairly well for a
first attempt. Everyone involved agreed that unit testing and XP practices
were a significant factor in the quality of the end result - which was a
very high quality product. QA was especially pleased that they had so much
input from the beginning and that most of the bugs they found were not of
the kind that should have been found earlier.

I have always been a believer in early testing, but that project gave me the
experience in a situation where the abandoning the old bad practices and
adopting the new good practices resulted in a difference like night and day.

> No argument there. My concern is that everyone wants to test, but not
> everyone has the same goals. In this case, I think it's important to
> identify each person's (role's?) goals, then partition the work in a
> way that there is sufficient overlap for crosschecking, but not so much
> that we're all doing Solo Testing, but duplicating effort.

In my experience most people don't want to test. Hell I got burnt out on it
after 7 years of doing nothing but QA and testing. Even people who write
unit code tests would rather develop production code than write test code (I
am happy doing either, but happier writing production code). In the project
I was involved in there wasn't a wall between the dedicated tester and the
production developer; we usually paired a tester with 1-2 developers, the
developers serving as mentors of a sort with regards to teaching these
people how to code. Many of them were people we brought in with the idea
that eventually they would be writing production code themselves, and many
of them eventually did - but by then they knew the value of unit testing and
defensive programming, and were more amenable to concepts such as TDD.

So, there was no real duplication of effort; unit testers more or less
picked up where developers had left off and added to or extended their unit
testing efforts. The unit testers also learned the codebase, and hopefully
learned food coding practices by being under the wing of more experienced
developers.


> I might approach the situation by explaining that the tests in TDD are
> not meant to test, but rather the guide the design. In that light,
> surely outside testing looks like a good idea.
>

I don't know that I would call it "outside" testing. We had a very
integrated team; in that project you were not a member of QA, a member of
development, or a member of marketing - you were a member of the team with a
certain expertise that the project needed. We had unit testers and we had
integration system testers, and everybody was one big happy family. ;-)

> This is where my ignorance shines. I don't know how to convince anyone
> of anything, so I'm content to let others try to do it.

I have found that leading by example with gentle persuasion generally works
well. Sometimes I have had to leave companies because few people there "got
it", and it was a lost cause until someone in power came in and turned
things around or upside down. It can take years for good practices to be
adopted and it takes patience. As long as there is progress and a
committment to improvement, then I can feel that I am accomplishing
something.

> Well, of course TDD won't find all the bugs. TDD isn't about finding
> bugs.

Then we are in agreement. Early testing, properly managed can accomplish a
higher quality product - and so I think there is room for a unit testing
effort that works in cooperation with TDD. I have seen it work and the
results were much better than waiting for testing to get involved later.

FWIW,
Lauren
